title: Commonly Used Port
descrption: Adversaries may communicate over a commonly used port to bypass firewalls or network detection systems and to blend with normal network activity to avoid more detailed inspection. They may use commonly open ports such asTCP:80 (HTTP)TCP:443 (HTTPS)TCP:25 (SMTP)TCP/UDP:53 (DNS)They may use the protocol associated with the port or a completely different protocol. For connections that occur internally within an enclave (such as those between a proxy or pivot node and other nodes), examples of common ports are TCP/UDP:135 (RPC)TCP/UDP:22 (SSH)TCP/UDP:3389 (RDP)
Data Sources: Packet capture, Netflow/Enclave netflow, Process use of network, Process monitoring

related.Name: ADVSTORESHELL
related.Description: A variant of ADVSTORESHELL attempts communication to the C2 server over HTTP on port 443.[38]

related.Name: APT18
related.Description: APT18 uses port 80 for C2 communications.[81][82]

related.Name: APT19
related.Description: APT19 used TCP port 80 for C2.[73]

related.Name: APT28
related.Description: APT28 has used port 443 for C2.[89]

related.Name: APT29
related.Description: APT29 has used Port Number 443 for C2.[87]

related.Name: APT3
related.Description: APT3 uses commonly used ports (like HTTPS/443) for command and control.[79]

related.Name: APT32
related.Description: APT32 has used port 80 for C2 communications.[31][80]

related.Name: APT33
related.Description: APT33 has used port 443 for command and control.[60]

related.Name: APT37
related.Description: APT37 has used port 8080 for C2.[78]

related.Name: AuditCred
related.Description: AuditCred has used Port Number 443 for C2 communications.[41]

related.Name: BADCALL
related.Description: BADCALL uses port 8000 and 443 for C2.[5]

related.Name: BadPatch
related.Description: BadPatch uses port 26 for C2 communications.[39]

related.Name: BBSRAT
related.Description: BBSRAT uses HTTP TCP port 80 and HTTPS TCP port 443 for communications.[34]

related.Name: Bisonal
related.Description: Bisonal uses 443 for C2 communications.[36]

related.Name: Briba
related.Description: Briba connects to external C2 infrastructure over port 443.[35]

related.Name: Calisto
related.Description: Calisto attempted to contact the C2 server over TCP using port 80.[22]

related.Name: Carbanak
related.Description: Carbanak uses Port Numbers 443 and 80 for the C2 server.[30]

related.Name: Carbon
related.Description: Carbon uses port 80 for C2 communications.[11]

related.Name: Cardinal RAT
related.Description: Cardinal RAT is downloaded using HTTP over port 443.[14]

related.Name: Cobalt Strike
related.Description: Cobalt Strike uses a custom command and control protocol that communicates over commonly used ports. The C2 protocol is encapsulated in common application layer protocols.[3]

related.Name: Comnie
related.Description: Comnie uses Port Numbers 80, 8080, 8000, and 443 for communication to the C2 servers.[46]

related.Name: Denis
related.Description: Denis uses port 53 for C2 communications.[31]

related.Name: Derusbi
related.Description: Derusbi beacons to destination port 443.[54]

related.Name: Dragonfly 2.0
related.Description: Dragonfly 2.0 used SMB over ports 445 or 139 for C2. The group also established encrypted connections over port 443.[85][86]

related.Name: Duqu
related.Description: Duqu uses a custom command and control protocol that communicates over commonly used ports, and is frequently encapsulated by application layer protocols.[6]

related.Name: Ebury
related.Description: Ebury has used UDP port 53 for C2.   [62]

related.Name: ELMER
related.Description: ELMER uses HTTP over port 443 for command and control.[13]

related.Name: Empire
related.Description: Empire can conduct command and control over commonly used ports like 80 and 443.[4]

related.Name: EvilGrab
related.Description: EvilGrab uses port 8080 for C2.[42]

related.Name: FELIXROOT
related.Description: FELIXROOT uses Port Numbers 443, 8443, and 8080 for C2 communications.[19][20]

related.Name: FIN7
related.Description: FIN7 has used ports 53, 80, 443, and 8080 for C2.[84]

related.Name: FIN8
related.Description: FIN8 has tunneled RDP backdoors over port 443.[72]

related.Name: FlawedAmmyy
related.Description: FlawedAmmyy has used port 443 for C2.[63]

related.Name: FlawedGrace
related.Description: FlawedGrace has used port 443 for C2 communications.[64]

related.Name: FTP
related.Description: FTP operates over ports 21 and 20.[2]

related.Name: Fysbis
related.Description: Fysbis has used port 80 for C2. [70]

related.Name: gh0st RAT
related.Description: gh0st RAT uses port 443 for C2 communications.[44]

related.Name: HARDRAIN
related.Description: HARDRAIN binds and listens on port 443.[37]

related.Name: HAWKBALL
related.Description: HAWKBALL has sent HTTP GET requests over port 443 for C2.[68]

related.Name: Hi-Zor
related.Description: Hi-Zor communicates with its C2 server over port 443.[23]

related.Name: HOPLIGHT
related.Description: HOPLIGHT has connected outbound over TCP port 443.   [61]

related.Name: HTTPBrowser
related.Description: One HTTPBrowser variant connected to its C2 server over port 8080.[7]

related.Name: InvisiMole
related.Description: InvisiMole uses port 80 for C2.[33]

related.Name: Ixeshe
related.Description: Ixeshe has used TCP port 443 for C2.[65]

related.Name: KeyBoy
related.Description: KeyBoy calls back to the C2 server over ports 53, 80, and 443.[66][67]

related.Name: KEYMARBLE
related.Description: KEYMARBLE uses port 443 for C2.[50]

related.Name: Lazarus Group
related.Description: Some Lazarus Group malware uses a list of ordered port numbers to choose a port for C2 traffic, which includes commonly used ports such as 443, 53, 80, 25, and 8080.[75][76]

related.Name: Linux Rabbit
related.Description: Linux Rabbit checks to see if an SSH server is listening on port 22.[55]

related.Name: LOWBALL
related.Description: LOWBALL command and control occurs via HTTPS over port 443.[9]

related.Name: Machete
related.Description: Machete used TCP port 21 for C2.[91]

related.Name: Magic Hound
related.Description: Magic Hound malware has communicated with C2 servers over port 6667 (for IRC) and port 8080.[71]

related.Name: MirageFox
related.Description: MirageFox uses port 80 for C2.[16]

related.Name: Mis-Type
related.Description: Mis-Type communicates over common ports such as TCP 80, 443, and 25.[12]

related.Name: Misdat
related.Description: Misdat network traffic communicates over common ports like 80, 443, or 1433.[12]

related.Name: Mivast
related.Description: Mivast communicates over port 80 for C2.[25]

related.Name: MoonWind
related.Description: MoonWind communicates over ports 80, 443, 53, and 8080 via raw sockets instead of the protocols usually associated with the ports.[32]

related.Name: Naid
related.Description: Naid connects to external C2 infrastructure over port 443.[47]

related.Name: Nidiran
related.Description: Nidiran communicates with its C2 domain over ports 443 and 8443.[48]

related.Name: Night Dragon
related.Description: Night Dragon has used ports 25 and 80 for C2 communications.[83]

related.Name: OceanSalt
related.Description: OceanSalt uses Port Number 8080 for C2.[40]

related.Name: OilRig
related.Description: OilRig has used port 80 to call back to the C2 server. [90]

related.Name: Pasam
related.Description: Pasam connects to external C2 infrastructure and opens a backdoor over port 443.[26]

related.Name: PlugX
related.Description: PlugX has beaconed to its C2 over port 443.[42][43]

related.Name: PowerDuke
related.Description: PowerDuke connects over 443 for C2.[51]

related.Name: POWERSTATS
related.Description: POWERSTATS has used port 80 for C2.[49]

related.Name: POWERTON
related.Description: POWERTON has used port 443 for C2 traffic. [60]

related.Name: Proxysvc
related.Description: Proxysvc uses port 443 for the control server communications.[10]

related.Name: RATANKBA
related.Description: RATANKBA uses port 443 for C2.[21]

related.Name: RedLeaves
related.Description: RedLeaves uses a specific port of 443 and can also use ports 53 and 80 for C2. One RedLeaves variant uses HTTP over port 443 to connect to its C2 server.[42][52]

related.Name: RIPTIDE
related.Description: RIPTIDE is a RAT that communicates with HTTP.[53]

related.Name: S-Type
related.Description: S-Type uses ports 80, 443, and 8080 for C2.[12]

related.Name: ServHelper
related.Description: ServHelper has used port 80 and 443 for C2.[64]

related.Name: Shamoon
related.Description: Shamoon has used TCP port 8080 for C2.[24]

related.Name: TEMP.Veles
related.Description: TEMP.Veles has used port 443 for C2.[88]

related.Name: Threat Group-3390
related.Description: C2 traffic for most Threat Group-3390 tools occurs over Port Numbers 53, 80, and 443.[77]

related.Name: TrickBot
related.Description: TrickBot uses port 443 for C2 communications.[17][18]

related.Name: Tropic Trooper
related.Description: Tropic Trooper can use ports 443 and 53 for C2 communications via malware called TClient.[74]

related.Name: TYPEFRAME
related.Description: TYPEFRAME variants can use ports 443, 8443, and 8080 for communications.[15]

related.Name: UBoatRAT
related.Description: UBoatRAT uses ports 80 and 443 for C2 communications.[45]

related.Name: Volgmer
related.Description: Some Volgmer variants use ports 8080 and 8000 for C2.[27][28][29]

related.Name: Wiarp
related.Description: Wiarp connects to external C2 infrastructure over the HTTP port.[8]

related.Name: ZxShell
related.Description: ZxShell uses common ports such as 80 and 443 for C2.[69]

Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. Signatures are often for unique indicators within protocols and may be based on the specific protocol used by a particular adversary or tool, and will likely be different across various malware families and versions. Adversaries will likely change tool C2 signatures over time or construct protocols in such a way as to avoid detection by common defensive tools.[1]
Configure internal and external firewalls to block traffic using common ports that associate to network protocols that may be unnecessary for that particular network segment.
